Highlights • The problem and proposed models apply to the background of EU ETS. • Reference-dependent theory integrated with Hotelling model is used. • Airline competition in pricing and green transportation investment is analyzed. • Consumer psychological benefits are considered in model formulation. Abstract This study presents a reference-dependent Hotelling model for analyzing airline competition in pricing and green transportation investment, as well as the resulting financial performance under the European Union emission trading scheme. One feature of the proposed methodology is that it embeds psychological benefits/costs of consumers to characterize consumer attitudes to the increases in airline fare adjustments and improvements in green transportation. This study then investigates the equilibrium solutions for airfare adjustment and green transportation investment margins in different scenarios. The analytical results reveal specific operational conditions under which a cost-efficient airline can gain supreme competitive advantage by increasing both airfare and green transportation investment margins beyond the increases made by competitors under the emission trading scheme, whereas certain specific conditions may favor a cost leadership strategy. Conversely, a cost-inefficient airline can compete with a cost-efficient airline in both market share and profitability using the green transportation investment-differentiation strategy, particularly when consumers perceive the airfare difference as equaling the increased psychological benefit induced by the airline’s green effort. Keywords Green transportation Behavioral economics Emission trading scheme Reference dependence 1 Introduction As global warming and anomalous climate change caused by carbon emissions become worldwide ecological issues, diverse emission trading schemes (ETSs), both voluntary and mandatory, have been proposed, and are operating for various industries (European Union, 2003; Brueckner and Zhang, 2010; Chen and Yang, 2012; Adler et al., 2013; Choi, 2013;Chen et al., 2014). One notable example is the European Union (EU) ETS, which since 2008 has included the aviation sector, and began to enforce the carbon permits (CPs) instrument in 2012 (Preston et al., 2012). The EU-ETS treats carbon as a commodity with a carbon price, and has set progressively reducing caps on annual greenhouse gas emissions. In 2012, annual carbon emission allowances (the cap) allocated to the aviation sector were set at 3% below the historical emissions for 2004–2006, and up to 5% below emissions for 2013 (European Commission, 2011). The EU ETS sets progressively reducing emission caps. 85% of the emission cap is to be distributed free in 2012, with the remaining 15% auctioned to the aviation sector, and carbon prices are forecast to range between €8–29 from 2008 to 2012 (EEX, 2009). Under the EU ETS, all flights departing from and arriving at EU airports are charged CPs to cover carbon emissions. The EU ETS is expected to see each global airline initially add €1–1.4 billion to its annual operational costs, eventually reaching €7 billion annually in 2020. More recently, in the 38th International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) general assembly the ICAO member states have achieved the consensus that the agreement of CPs calls for inter-state consultations and negotiations” when creating new and implementing existing market-based measures (IATA, 2013). Facing the potential impact of the EU ETS and increasing uncertainty in green regulations globally, global airlines must be sufficiently agile in undertaking ambidextrous competitive strategies to not only quickly respond to rapid changes in volatile global political environments, but also to achieve sustainable competitive advantage. As the EU ETS impact on aviation is an emerging global issue affecting the transnational public and private sectors, a growing body of literature is addressing this issue from different perspectives (Morrell, 2007; Scheelhaase et al., 2010; Anger and Kohler, 2010; Sheu and Li, 2013). Morrell (2007) investigated the impacts of the EU ETS on selected airlines, including low-cost carriers and full-service carriers, and presented analytical results indicating that the ETS-induced impact on low-cost carriers generally exceeds that on full-service carriers. Scheelhaase et al. (2010) compared the effects of the EU-ETS on the competitiveness of European and third-country airlines, and concluded that third-country airlines are more likely to achieve significant competitive advantage than European airlines in the long-haul market. Furthermore, Anger and Kohler (2010) reviewed the literature on the impact of including aviation emissions in the EU ETS, and concluded that the EU ETS is unlikely to significantly impact growth in aviation demand. Nevertheless, Anger and Kohler (2010) proposed directions for future research on the nature of aviation competition, cost pass-through rates, pricing, and marginal abatement cost curves for airlines. Using a classical Hotelling model, Sheu and Li investigated the effect of carbon permits under the cap-and-trade scheme on competition and green transportation strategies of global airlines. Differing from the proposed method of Sheu and Li (2013), this work integrates the Hotelling model with reference dependence theory (Kahneman and Tversky, 1979) to characterize consumers’ valuation of green service and image attributed to airlines’ relative green effort, thus facilitating the approximation of demand shifts between competing airlines. Motivated by these early studies, this study addresses airline competition by investigating and comparing the corresponding equilibrium solutions and resulting profits of competing airlines obtained before and after the implementation of EU-ETS. This study thus considers airfare pricing and investment in green transportation as two main measures of competitiveness under EU-ETS. Furthermore, this study provides additional managerial insights, including specific conditions and competitive strategies favorable for both cost-efficient and cost-inefficient airlines. Furthermore, some of the literature focuses on the costs associated with ETS and their impact on demand (Vivid Economics, 2007; Sascha et al., 2009; Carmona and Hinz, 2011; Malina et al., 2012; Tsai et al., 2012). Consensus exists that the inclusion of aviation in the EU-ETS directly influences airline operating costs, further affecting market demand. Factors such as unit carbon-trading-induced costs and cost pass-through rates are attracting growing researcher attention. Particularly, researchers tend to correlate unit carbon-trading-induced cost with fuel use and CO2 emissions (kg) per kg of fuel for different aircraft and flight routes when performing cost analysis (Vivid Economics, 2007;Sascha et al., 2009; Malina et al., 2012;Tsai et al., 2012). For instance, Sascha et al. (2009) examined the effects of carbon-trading-induced costs on passenger demand at the individual route level, and found that when CO2 is priced at €20/ton, airline operational costs increase to €9–27 per route under EU-ETS. Given a per ton CO2 price of €15, Malina et al. (2012) analyzed the impact of the EU-ETS on US aviation in three pass-through scenarios using an economy-wide general equilibrium model combined with a partial equilibrium model. Their concluding remarks infer that US airlines obtain higher profits in the case of a full cost pass-through rate under EU ETS. Conversely, some researchers claim that the cost pass-through rate depends on business models and routes, and ranges between 40% and 150% of the unit carbon-trading-induced costs (Boon et al., 2007;Morrell, 2007; Scheelhaase et al., 2010; Vivid Economics, 2007). Mason (2005) further demonstrated that the impact of the EU ETS on normal-service airlines can exceed expectations since not all business-class travelers are price-inelastic. Based on the above literature, this study identifies room to investigate airline competition strategies, and the impacts on their market share and profits under EU ETS. This study contributes to understanding of this area by incorporating the reference-dependent theory into the Hotelling model to characterize consumer response to airfare adjustment by competing airlines and improvement in green transportation at the individual level, followed by approximating the change in the market shares of competing airlines at the demand market level. The use of such an integrated behavioral framework to project potential changes in aggregate passenger demand under EU ETS helps bridge the gap between individual choice behavior and demand market projection in the previous literature. Additionally, the previous literature on airline solutions for solving emission reduction problems under EU-ETS remains limited (Sgouridis et al., 2011). Sgouridis et al. (2011) investigated the influence of five emissions reduction policies using a system dynamics modeling approach, and concluded that no single policy can efficiently control carbon emissions under projected increasing demand for air transportation. Motivated by Sgouridis et al. (2011), this study primarily considered airfare adjustment and investment in green transportation practices (e.g., actions and resources for saving energy and eco-friendly transportation) as the two primary measures airlines are likely to adopt in response to the EU ETS. Airfare adjustment is a reactive measure as it is intended to alleviate the impact of ETS on airline economic performance. Conversely, investment in green transportation practices is a proactive measure since it exerts a long-term and sustainable effect on airline company performance, helping reduce carbon emissions. Considering these two measures helps characterize the short- and long-term competing strategies of airlines in achieving sustainable development of business in the emerging ETS context. This study investigates equilibrium solutions for airfare pricing and green transportation investment of airlines under the EU ETS. This study aims to fill the gap between the analysis of the impact of the EU ETS on price competition and strategic solutions via investment in green transportation and the development of sustainable aviation. Considering the lack of knowledge of airline sustainable operations and competitive strategies in response to the CP instrument introduced by the EU ETS, this study investigates equilibrium solutions for improving airline competitiveness in airfare pricing and green transportation investment (GTI) for achieving sustainable development in the EU ETS context. Compared with the previous literature, this study contributes to the field of green transportation via the following three methodological perspectives. 1. In model development and analysis, this study investigates the effect of EU-CP instrument on competition in the aviation market in different strategic scenarios. Extended from a baseline model based on symmetric duopoly competition without the CP instrument, this study formulates different player response functions to characterize the hybrid use of competing strategies in airfare adjustment and GTI by airlines in the EU-CP contexts. A game-theoretic approach is then adopted to seek equilibrium solutions for competing airlines under different scenarios for analysis and discussion. 2. By integrating the Hotelling model (Hotelling, 1929) with reference dependence theory (Kahneman and Tversky, 1979;Thaler, 1985; Koszegi and Rabin, 2006), this study conceptualizes consumer attitudes regarding the green-service value of airlines with psychological benefits to create a consumer value that underlies both passenger demand and airline response. Rooted in the concept of consumer value in marketing areas (Zeithaml, 1988; Bolton and Drew, 1991; Woodruff, 1997), this work regards green-service value as a customer’s overall assessment of a firm’s efforts and performance in green improvements. Specifically, this study asserts that consumer attitudes toward airline green-service value are reference-dependent, and specifically depend on the instantaneous reference point the consumer chooses, according to the theory of reference dependence (Kahneman and Tversky, 1979; Thaler, 1985; Koszegi and Rabin, 2006). Accordingly, this study proposes a reference-dependent Hotelling model to characterize consumer reference-dependent attitude to green-service value, which is measured with a uniform distribution [0, 1]. The resulting passenger utility can then be used to determine airline market shares and competitive strategies. 3. Drawing on the early literature on green consumer behavior (Kassarjian, 1971;Bamberg, 2003; Hartmann and Apaolaza-Ibanez, 2011), this study incorporates additional psychological costs into the proposed model to characterize the changes in consumer attitude toward green-service value when choosing airlines which increase airfares and invest in green transportation by different margins in the ETS context. This is followed by approximating the change in market share, and then seeking equilibrium solutions of competing airlines. Such a psychological economics approach appears more theoretically reasonable than classical price-dependent-only demand functions in characterizing consumer response to perceived airfare adjustment and airline efforts to realize green transportation. More specifically, this study defines extra psychological costs of consumers as consumer perceptions of airfare adjustment minus the green-service value associated with an airline. Utilizing this idea, the proposed method permits the rationalization of the phenomenon of some consumers being willing to pay more for greener products/services while others are not (Ginsberg and Bloom, 2004). The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 describes the baseline and extended models used to examine the effect of CP instrument on price competition and airline GTI in different strategic scenarios. Section 3 then performs qualitative analyses and a numerical study focused on the case of the EU-CP instrument using the derived equilibrium solutions for airline airfare readjustment and investment in green transportation practices. Finally, Section 4 presents concluding remarks and recommends future research directions. 2 Models 2.1 Baseline model (without CP instrument) Consider two airlines, A and B, which provide passengers with air transportation services (denoted as a and b, respectively) with airfares p A and p B , respectively. The marginal operational costs of airlines A and B are c A and c B , respectively. Notably, this study normalizes all the cost and demand variable values to facilitate analysis. To model consumer preference heterogeneity, this study adopts the proposal of Zhou (2011) for a reference-dependent Hotelling setting that combines the classical Hotelling model (Hotelling, 1929) and reference dependence theory (Kahneman and Tversky, 1979;Thaler, 1985; Koszegi and Rabin, 2006) to characterize consumer reference-dependent preferences under uncertainty. It is worth mentioning that the reference-dependence theory is applicable particularly for characterizing consumer reference-dependent preferences and resulting choice behavior through comparisons of target objects (e.g., prices, services, and brands), according to the literature (Kahneman and Tversky, 1979; Thaler, 1985; Koszegi and Rabin, 2006). In formulating the baseline model, we argue that normally consumers may compare airfares offered by different airlines (e.g., comparing the airfare offered by airline A with that by B, or airfare offered by airline B with that by A) before making decisions, thus applying the theory to characterize such price-dependent consumer behavior. Consider a unit mass of consumers, each with unit demand for air transportation services, (based on individual airline preferences where individual airline preferences influence that demand). Let consumer preferences regarding ideal air transportation services be represented by a point x, which is assumed to be uniformly distributed over the range [0, 1] (i.e, ∀x ∈[0, 1]), where airlines A and B occupy the endpoints of this uniform distribution, namely 0 and 1, respectively. Moreover, a consumer with a preference for the service of airline B at level x is labeled consumer x. Fig. 1 shows the Hotelling setting for characterizing consumer preference heterogeneity. Now, consider the attitude of consumer x toward the services provided by airlines A and B in the absence of the “loss aversion” effect (i.e., assuming a risk neutral consumer). Let v denote consumer valuation of an ideal air transportation service, independent of considerations associated with individual airlines. If airline A is chosen, consumer x must pay transaction cost −x in the psychological domain (termed psychological transaction cost), and the intrinsic service value (v a ) attributed to the attitude toward a of consumer x is then given by v a = v − x − p A . Conversely, if consumer x selects airline B, the intrinsic service value (v b ) attributed to the attitude toward b of consumer x is given by v b = v −(1− x)− p B . Nevertheless, reference dependence theory (Kahneman and Tversky, 1979;Thaler, 1985; Koszegi and Rabin, 2006) has demonstrated that a person’s value assessment toward an object (e.g., a product, service, and bet) depend on the person’s expectation of the induced value (e.g., gains and losses) relative to a reference point. Therein, the effect of loss expectation is frequently greater than that of gain expectation on a person’s valuation. Applying such a property of reference dependence theory, this study argues that consumers are likely to exhibit reference-dependent preferences with the loss aversion effect in their psychological assessment of airlines. Specifically, if consumer x considers a a reference point, then their reference-dependent attitude (V a∣a ) toward a is the same as that toward v a (i.e., V a∣a = v a = v − x − p A ); however, the reference-dependent consumer attitude (V b∣a ) toward b becomes (1) V b | a = v b + wu b | a Eq. (1) is a generalized form of a typical reference-dependent model (Koszegi and Rabin, 2006) which comprises intrinsic utility (i.e., the first term) and a weighted reference-dependent service value (i.e., the second term), where u b∣a represents the additional reference-dependent utility attributed to consumer perceived value of b relative to a; and w is a weight ( w ∈ R + ) characterizing the relative influence of u b∣a in V b∣a . In this study, u b∣a is given by u b | a = - λ b | a T Φ b | a , where λ b∣a denotes a loss aversion coefficient vector λ b | a ≡ λ b | a p λ b | a x associated with the reference-dependent attribute vector Φ b | a Φ b | a ≡ ϕ b | a p ϕ b | a x ≡ p b - p a 1 - 2 x . In this study, λ b | a p and λ b | a x λ b | a p ⩾ 1 , λ b | a x ⩾ 1 represent two loss aversion parameters, which characterize the degree of consumer sensitivity to losses rather than gains relative to a reference point-“service a” in the price (p) and psychological transaction cost (x) domains, respectively. Based on Kahneman and Tversky (1979), λ b | a p and λ b | a x are given, respectively, by λ b | a p = λ p , if ϕ b | a p > 0 1 , if ϕ b | a p ⩽ 0 and λ b | a x = λ x , if 1 - x > x 1 , if 1 - x ⩽ x , where λ p and λ x are p-specific and x-specific loss aversion coefficients subject to λ p >1 and λ x >1. If such a loss-aversion effect is not considered, the standard Hotelling model replaces the proposed model. Similarly, if consumer x regards “service b” as a reference point, then their reference-dependent attitude (V b∣b ) toward b remains (i.e., V b∣b = v b = v −(1− x)− p B ); however, the reference-dependent attitude (V a∣b ) toward a becomes (2) V a | b = v a + wu a | b where u a∣b represents the additional reference-dependent utility attributed to consumer perceived value of a relative to b. In this study, u a∣b can be further expressed as u a | b = - λ a | b T Φ a | b , where λ a∣b is a loss aversion coefficient vector λ a | b ≡ λ a | b p λ a | b x associated with the reference-dependent attribute vector Φ a | b ( Φ a | b ≡ ϕ a | b p ϕ a | b x ≡ p a - p b 2 x - 1 = - Φ b | a ) . Like λ b | a p and λ b | a x , λ a | b p and λ a | b x are given, respectively, by λ a | b p = λ p , if ϕ a | b p > 0 1 , if ϕ a | b p ⩽ 0 and λ a | b x = λ x , if x > 1 - x 1 , if x ⩽ 1 - x . Using p A (p B ) and p B (p A ) (Eqs. (8) and (9)) can obtain the equilibrium solutions of p A and p B (denoted by p A ∗ and p B ∗ ) for different cost conditions, as described in Proposition 2.2. Proposition 2.2 Given α, w, λ p , λ x , c A , and c B , it is possible to determine p A ∗ and p B ∗ by: (a) p A ∗ = 2 c A + c B 3 + 1 2 K , and p B ∗ = 2 c B + c A 3 + 1 2 K (when c A < c B ); (b) p A ∗ = p B ∗ = c + 1 (when c ≡ c A = c B ); (c) p A ∗ = 2 c A + c B 3 + 1 2 L , and p B ∗ = 2 c B + c A 3 + 1 2 L (when c A > c B ). Proposition 2.2 indicates that p A ∗ and p B ∗ are determined by two categories of parameters: supply-oriented (i.e., c A and c B ) and demand-oriented (i.e., K and L) parameters. Therein, c A and c B are determined by airline’s operational performance, and thus, controllable to airlines themselves. By contrast, K and L are determined by α, w, λ p , and λ x which are attributed to customer attitudes with psychological and behavioral uncertainties. As such, K and L which are regarded as influencing factors of external environments are not controllable to airlines, thus requiring additional market demand analyses (e.g., customer behavior analysis) for parameter quantification. Nevertheless, using Proposition 2.2 it is easy for airlines to adopt the following adaptive airfare strategy which requires continuous response to competing airlines’ prices as a price competition strategy. For example, given airline A as a cost-efficient airline (i.e., c A < c B ) the optimal solution p A ∗ for the airfare pricing of airline A is to continuously adjust its airfare subject to the condition p B - p A ∗ = c B - c A 3 (by Proposition 2.2(a)) no matter what p B and demand-oriented (i.e., K and L) parameters are. 2.2 Extended Model 1 (with CP instrument) This subsection extends the baseline model to investigate the market competition of airlines A and B given the application of the CP instrument to the aviation industry. The equilibrium solutions of airfares ( p A ∗ and p B ∗ ) derived for the case without the CP instrument remain used as a foundation for investigating the effect of CP instrument on changes in airfares in this scenario. Compared with the scenario without CP instrument (subsection 2.1), this scenario mainly addresses the issue of the influences of the CP-induced cost pass-through rates adopted by competing airlines on passenger demand and airfares. The scenario assumes that the unit CP charged to all airlines is constant, as in the EU-ETS case, and thus, assumes the same marginal CP-induced cost (c cp ) is imposed on airlines A and B. Nevertheless, the CP-induced cost pass-through rates (Δp A and Δp B ) associated with airlines A and B can differ with airline decisions, where Δp A and Δp B (Δp A ⩾0, Δp B ⩾0) refer to the additional costs that a customer should pay for services a and b, respectively, under the CP instrument. This study considers Δp A and Δp B as decision variables associated with airlines A and B. Below, this study investigates the influence of Δp A and Δp B on passenger demand and airline competition in airfare pricing. Given that consumer x perceives increases in airfares (i.e., Δp A and Δp B ) under the CP instrument, the perceived new airfares ( p ˆ A and p ˆ B ) charged by airlines A and B may increase by up to p ˆ A ≡ p A ∗ + Δ p A and p ˆ B ≡ p B ∗ + Δ p B , respectively. Furthermore, this study posits that the perceived increases in airfares may also increase the consumer’s psychological transaction cost in the x-domain. For instance, consumers typically dislike unexpected increases in airfares, particularly if they perceive an airline to be actively and voluntarily increasing airfares compared to other airlines. Thus, this study infers that a consumer is likely to compare the degrees of increases in airfares among competing airlines, and find that consumer psychological transaction cost increases with airfares. For a consumer x, the reference-dependent attitudes (Eq. The CP instrument is likely to contribute to the collective increases (i.e., (Δp A ⩾0)∧(Δp B ⩾0)) in airfares of airlines A and B. However, the induced effect on the changes (Δq A and Δq B ) in market demands is mixed, and depends on the difference in the optimal airfares p B ∗ - p A ∗ under equilibrium conditions without the CP instrument, and on relative increases (Δp A −Δp B ) in airfares adopted by these two competing airlines under a CP regime. For instance, consider the case when the increase in airfare by airline A exceeds that by airline B (i.e., Δp A >Δp B ). To derive the equilibrium solutions for the price competition of airlines A and B for the CP instrument scenario, we can revise the profit functions (Eqs. (6) and (7)) of airlines A and B as (15) Max π ˆ A ( p ˆ A , p ˆ B ) = π A ( Δ p A , Δ p B ) = p A ∗ + Δ p A - c A - c cp q ˆ A ( Δ p A , Δ p B ) (16) Max π ˆ B ( p ˆ A , p ˆ B ) = π B ( Δ p A , Δ p B ) = p B ∗ + Δ p B - c B - c cp q ˆ B ( Δ p A , Δ p B ) where q ˆ A ( Δ p A , Δ p B ) and q ˆ B ( Δ p A , Δ p B ) are defined in Lemma 2.2. (15) and (16) with respect to Δp A and Δp B , it is possible to obtain the Δp A (Δp B ) and Δp B (Δp A ) associated with airlines A, and B, respectively. We can then derive Theorem 2.1, which characterizes the equilibrium solutions ( Δ p A ∗ and Δ p B ∗ ) for airfare adjustment of competing airlines in response to the CP instrument in the absence of GTI. Theorem 2.1 Given p A ∗ and p B ∗ (by Proposition 2.2 ) for the case without the CP instrument, the equilibrium solutions for airfare adjustments of competing airlines are Δ p A ∗ = Δ p B ∗ = c cp in response to the CP instrument for the case without GTI. Theorem 2.1 indicates that under the CP instrument, each competing airline tends to increase airfares as much as possible to compensate for the additional costs associated with CP; meanwhile, the potential reduction in market share resulting from increases in airfares compared with competing airlines is a concern. Consequently, competing airlines are likely to collude to simultaneously adopt 100% as the cost pass-through rate (i.e., Δ p A ∗ = Δ p B ∗ = c cp ) to cover the costs associated with CP. This analytical result also implies that the CP-induced increases in airfares are unrelated to the instantaneous airfares and operational cost conditions of competing airlines. 2.3 Extended Model 2 (with CP instrument and GTI) This subsection further considers the case where competing airlines adopt GTI in the CP instrument context. For convenience in differentiating competing airlines based on their GTI practices, this study introduces new variables θ A and θ B (0⩽ θ A , θ B ⩽1), which represent the degrees of GTI adoption by airlines A and B, respectively. Next, this study considers the potential changes in the attitudes of consumer x toward airline services with GTI when choosing airlines in a scenario with CP. Motivated by consumer value creation (Bolton and Drew, 1991;Woodruff, 1997) and environmental consumerism (Menon and Menon, 1997;Ginsberg and Bloom, 2004), we hypothesize that airline GTI positively affects consumer attitude toward airline service. For instance, consumer x may happily support airlines implementing GTI as a means of protecting the environment. Thus, an additional utility (Δv i ) dependent on degree of GTI (θ i ) is created if consumer x chooses airline i (i = A, B). Let Δv i ≡ tθ i , where t represents the marginal effect of θ i on Δv i (∀i). Assume that consumer x perceives both the increases (i.e., Δ p ̃ A and Δ p ̃ B ) in airfares and GTI (θ A and θ B ) associated with airlines A and B in the CP instrument context during airline selection. As Δv A (Δv A ≡ tθ A ) and Δv B (Δv A ≡ tθ A ) can be regarded as mental benefits, in contrast with psychological transaction cost ( - x ̃ ) , they can be incorporated into the psychological transaction cost-domain to characterize the attitudes of consumer x towards the service of airlines A and B in this scenario. Theorem 2.2 Given α, w, λ p , λ x , s, t, c cp , c A , and c B , then in the CP-instrument context, the equilibrium solutions for airfare readjustment ( Δ p ̃ A ∗ and Δ p ̃ B ∗ ) and GTI ( θ A ∗ and θ B ∗ ) of competing airlines exist if one of the following four necessary conditions holds; moreover, θ A ∗ and θ B ∗ are mutually dependent. (a) If ( c A < c B ) ∧ θ A ∗ ⩾ 3 - 2 ( c B - c A ) K 2 ( t - s ) K ∧ max { Δ P A - Δ P B , 0 } < p B ∗ - p A ∗ , and given θ A ∗ , then (24) Δ p ̃ A ∗ = c cp + s θ A ∗ + 1 2 K - ( c B - c A ) 3 Δ p ̃ B ∗ = c cp + s θ A ∗ - ( 2 s + t ) [ 3 - 2 ( c B - c A ) K ] 6 ( t - s ) K θ B ∗ = θ A ∗ - 3 - 2 ( c B - c A ) K 2 ( t - s ) K (b) If ( c A > c B ) ∧ θ B ∗ ⩾ 3 - 2 ( c A - c B ) L 2 ( t - s ) L ∧ max { Δ P A - Δ P B , 0 } > p B ∗ - p A ∗ , and given θ B ∗ , then (25) Δ p ̃ A ∗ = c cp + s θ B ∗ - ( 2 s + t ) [ 3 - 2 ( c A - c B ) L ] 6 ( t - s ) L Δ p ̃ B ∗ = c cp + s θ B ∗ + 1 2 L - c A - c B 3 θ A ∗ = θ B ∗ - 3 - 2 ( c A - c B ) L 2 ( t - s ) L (c) If ( c A = c B ) ∧ Δ P A ∗ - Δ P B ∗ = p B ∗ - p A ∗ , then (26) θ A ∗ = θ B ∗ ≡ θ ∗ , and Δ p ̃ A ∗ = Δ p ̃ B ∗ = c cp + s θ ∗ (d) If ( c A < c B ) ∧ θ B ∗ ⩾ c B - c A t - s ∧ p B ∗ - p A ∗ > 0 ∧ Δ P A ∗ - Δ P B ∗ = p B ∗ - p A ∗ , then (27) Δ p ̃ A ∗ = c cp + s θ A ∗ - ( c B - c A ) 3 Δ p ̃ B ∗ = c cp + s θ A ∗ + ( 2 s + t ) ( c B - c A ) 3 ( t - s ) θ B ∗ = θ A ∗ + c B - c A t - s Theorem 2.2 identifies four respective regions to verify the existence of the equilibrium solutions for airfare readjustment ( Δ p ̃ A ∗ and Δ p ̃ B ∗ ) and GTI ( θ A ∗ and θ B ∗ ) of competing airlines in the EU-CP contexts. In Theorem 2.2, the symbol “ˆ” is a well-known logic operator meaning “and” in mathematics. As indicated in Eqs. (24)–(26), these equilibrium solutions are contingent on the difference in unit operational costs (c A − c B ) and the sequence of GTI measures ( θ A ∗ and θ B ∗ ) adopted by competing airlines. This study thus provides three generalizations observed from Theorem 2.2 for discussion. Observation 2.1 The equilibrium solutions for airfare adjustment of competing airlines and GTI measures exist when the cost-efficient airline is also the leading airline in GTI (by Theorem 2.2(a) and (b)). Moreover, the resulting GTI margin of the leader airline exceeds that of the follower airline. Observation 2.2 When competing airlines are cost-indifferent (c A = c B ), the margins of airfare adjustment and GTI adopted by competing airlines are the same under equilibrium conditions, as indicated in Theorem 2.2(c). Observation 2.3 The equilibrium solutions for airfare adjustment of competing airlines and GTI measures exist when the cost-efficient airline adopts both low-margin airfare adjustment and low-margin GTI subject to the condition p B ∗ - p A ∗ = Δ P A ∗ - Δ P B ∗ , as indicated in Theorem 2.2(d). Combining Observations 2.1 and 2.3 shows that a cost-efficient airline (i.e., the airline with lower unit operational costs described in this study) retains an advantage in utilizing the GTI measure in response to the CP instrument. If the cost-efficient airline also leads in GTI, a high-margin GTI strategy can be used to sustain its competitive advantage in demand markets by increasing market share; otherwise, a low-margin GTI combined with low-margin airfare adjustment can be utilized to strategically respond to the high-margin GTI measure adopted by its competitor. Furthermore, this study observes that the factors influencing equilibrium solutions can be classified into two categories: (1) cost-related parameters (c A , c B , c cp , and s), and (2) demand-related parameters (α, t, w, λ p and λ x ). We summarize the associated analytical results in Corollary 2.4 which is presented in online Appendix A (A8) considering the space limit. 3 Analysis Table B-1 (online Appendix B) summarizes the equilibrium solutions for competition among airlines in airfare adjustment and GTI, as well as resulting market demand and profits in the above three scenarios. Based on the derived equilibrium solutions and performance, this study performs qualitative and quantitative analyses to further reveal airline competition under the CP instrument in the following two subsections (subsections 3.1 and 3.2). To facilitate the following analyses and discussion, let Scenarios I, II, and III represent the cases without CP and GTI (for the baseline model), with CP (for extended model 1), and with CP and GTI (for extended model 2), respectively; all the variables (e.g., χ ∗(I), χ ∗(II), and χ ∗(II)) associated with I, II, and III are defined as the outputs derived using the corresponding models under the equilibrium conditions in Scenarios I, II, and III, respectively. 3.1 Qualitative analysis and results This subsection provides several managerial insights drawn from optimal solutions and analytical results obtained in different scenarios to address specific issues raised in this study. 3.1.1 Issue 1 – Will the CP instrument influence the performance of competing airlines? Corollary 3.1 Given α, w, λ p , λ x , c A , and c B , then under equilibrium conditions q A ∗ ( I ) = q A ∗ ( II ) , q B ∗ ( I ) = q B ∗ ( II ) , π A ∗ ( I ) = π A ∗ ( II ) , π B ∗ ( I ) = π B ∗ ( II ) . Corollary 3.1 indicates that the CP instrument does not influence the market share and profits of competing airlines if they merely compete via airfare adjustment (i.e., GTI strategies are not used). In reality, Corollary 3.1 can be easily proved using Eqs. (15) and (16), and Theorem 2.1 and Lemma 2.2. According to Theorem 2.1, competing airlines are likely to raise airfares by the same margin, i.e., Δ p A ∗ ( II ) = Δ p B ∗ ( II ) = c cp , under equilibrium conditions in response to the CP instrument, resulting in their market share remaining unchanged compared with Scenario I (namely, the case without the CP instrument), i.e., q A ∗ ( II ) = q A ∗ ( I ) and q B ∗ ( II ) = q B ∗ ( I ) by Lemma 2.2. Consequently, the profits of competing airlines remain unchanged, i.e., π A ∗ ( II ) = π A ∗ ( I ) and π B ∗ ( II ) = π B ∗ ( I ) . Corollary 3.2 Given the necessary conditions of Theorem 2.2 , and letting c B - c A = 3 2 K ( when c A < c B ) or c A - c B = 3 2 L ( when c A > c B ) hold, then ( a ) p A ∗ ( I ) = c A + 1 / K p B ∗ ( I ) = c B = c A + 3 / 2 K , q A ∗ ( I ) = 1 q B ∗ ( I ) = 0 , π A ∗ ( I ) = 1 / K π B ∗ ( I ) = 0 ( when c A < c B ) , or p A ∗ ( I ) = c A = c B + 3 / 2 L p B ∗ ( I ) = c B + 1 / L , q A ∗ ( I ) = 0 q B ∗ ( I ) = 1 , π A ∗ ( I ) = 0 π B ∗ ( I ) = 1 / L ( when c A > c B ) ; and ( b ) q A ∗ ( I ) = q A ∗ ( II ) = q A ∗ ( III ) q B ∗ ( I ) = q B ∗ ( II ) = q B ∗ ( III ) and π A ∗ ( I ) = π A ∗ ( II ) = π A ∗ ( III ) π B ∗ ( I ) = π B ∗ ( II ) = π B ∗ ( III ) Corollary 3.2 reveals a specific condition, either c B - c A = 3 2 K (when when c A < c B ) or c A - c B = 3 2 L (when c A > c B ), which ensures that a cost-efficient airline (i.e., an airline with a lower unit operational cost) can gain sustainable competitive advantage in all three scenarios. Under the above condition, the margins of the GTI of competing airlines are the same in Scenario III (i.e., θ A ∗ ( III ) = θ B ∗ ( III ) ≡ θ ∗ ). Additionally, the resulting margins of the airfare adjustments of competing airlines in Scenarios II or III are also the same (i.e., Δ p A ∗ ( II ) = Δ p B ∗ ( II ) = c cp , and Δ p A ∗ ( III ) = Δ p B ∗ ( III ) = c cp + s θ ∗ ) . This result indicates that a cost-coefficient airline (e.g., airline A) can adopt an always-low-price strategy such that its airfares are always lower than those of competitors (e.g., airfare B). Consequently, the cost-efficient airline gains a dominant market share with its market share equaling 1, e.g., q A ∗ ( I ) = 1 when c A < c B ) even if its competitor adopts the same airfare adjustments and GTI margins in market competition. Corollary 3.2 can be easily proved by setting either c B - c A = 3 2 K (when c A < c B ) or c A - c B = 3 2 L (when c A > c B ) to obtain the equilibrium solutions in these cases, and thus the corresponding proof is not provided. 3.1.2 Issue 2 – How will airfare adjustment and GTI strategies influence competing airline performance in the CP instrument context Proposition 3.1 Given the necessary conditions of Theorem 2.2 (a), let C1 and C2 represent two specific conditions, where C 1 ≡ c B - c A > s + 2 t 2 sK ∧ t - s > 0 ∨ 0 < c B - c A < s + 2 t 2 sK ∧ t - s < 0 , C 2 ≡ c B - c A > s + 2 t 2 sK ∧ t - s < 0 ∨ 0 < c B - c A < s + 2 t 2 sK ∧ t - s > 0 , and then, we have ( a ) p A ∗ ( I ) < p B ∗ ( I ) , p A ∗ ( III ) < p B ∗ ( III ) Δ p A ∗ ( III ) < Δ p B ∗ ( III ) θ A ∗ ( III ) < θ B ∗ ( III ) q A ∗ ( I ) > q B ∗ ( I ) , q A ∗ ( III ) > q B ∗ ( III ) π A ∗ ( I ) > π B ∗ ( I ) , π A ∗ ( III ) > π B ∗ ( III ) ( if C 1 holds ) ; or p A ∗ ( I ) < p B ∗ ( I ) , p A ∗ ( III ) > p B ∗ ( III ) Δ p A ∗ ( III ) > Δ p B ∗ ( III ) θ A ∗ ( III ) > θ B ∗ ( III ) q A ∗ ( I ) > q B ∗ ( I ) , q A ∗ ( III ) > q B ∗ ( III ) π A ∗ ( I ) > π B ∗ ( I ) , π A ∗ ( III ) > π B ∗ ( III ) ( if C 2 holds ) ( b ) q A ∗ ( I ) < q A ∗ ( III ) , q B ∗ ( I ) > q B ∗ ( III ) π A ∗ ( I ) > π A ∗ ( III ) , π B ∗ ( I ) > π B ∗ ( III ) ( if C 1 holds ) ; or q A ∗ ( I ) < q A ∗ ( III ) , q B ∗ ( I ) > q B ∗ ( III ) π A ∗ ( I ) < π A ∗ ( III ) , π B ∗ ( I ) > π B ∗ ( III ) ( if C 2 holds ) Proposition 3.1 reveals two specific conditions (C1 and C2) which determine two complementary regions characterized by the domains of relative cost-efficiency (c B − c A ) and GTI-induced marginal profit (denoted by t − s), as shown in Fig. 5 . Several managerial insights are presented below, where airline A is defined as the leader airline as it is a cost-efficient and GTI-leading airline, compared to airline B, which is termed a follower. First, in the C1 region, the leader airline is likely to adopt a cost leadership strategy in the example presented here. According to Porter (1985), a ”cost leadership strategy” involves providing standardized service and controlling all costs and expenses, thus enabling an airline to charge lower airfares than competitors. Such a cost-control feature is evident in Proposition 3.1(a) when C1 holds, where the margins of airfare adjustment ( i . e . , Δ p A ∗ ( III ) < Δ p B ∗ ( III ) ) and GTI i . e . , θ A ∗ ( III ) < θ B ∗ ( III ) adopted by the leader airline are smaller than those adopted by the follower airline, thus leading to the phenomenon that p A ∗ ( III ) < p B ∗ ( III ) . Conversely, in the C2 region the leader airline tends to adopt a ”differentiation strategy” which aims to differentiate the services offered by the airline from those offered by its competitors through devising unique services (Porter, 1985). Consequently, the resulting margins of airfare adjustment and GTI, and the airfares of the leading airline can be higher than those of competitors (i.e., Δ p A ∗ ( III ) > Δ p B ∗ ( III ) and θ A ∗ ( III ) > θ B ∗ ( III ) , and p A ∗ ( III ) > p B ∗ ( III ) ) as observed in Proposition 3.1(a) given condition C2. Additionally, this study observes that regardless of which condition (C1 or C2) holds, the resulting market share and profits of the leading airline exceed those of the follower airline in Scenarios I and III (Proposition 3.1(a)). In contrast, Proposition 3.1(b) reveals airline relative performance in market share and profits obtained before and after the implementation of the CP instrument and GTI. Comparison with the follower airline reveals that the leader airline obtains absolute advantage in market share either before or after the implementation of the CP-instrument, but does not mean that the profits obtained in Scenario III also increase. Instead, the resulting profits gained by the leader airline are guaranteed to increase only when condition C2 holds, implying the outperformance of a differentiation strategy over a cost-leadership strategy in the CP-instrument context. Corollary 3.3 Given the necessary condition of Theorem 2.2 (d), then ( a ) p A ∗ ( I ) < p B ∗ ( I ) , p A ∗ ( III ) < p B ∗ ( III ) Δ p A ∗ ( III ) < Δ p B ∗ ( III ) θ A ∗ ( III ) < θ B ∗ ( III ) q A ∗ ( I ) > q B ∗ ( I ) , q A ∗ ( III ) = q B ∗ ( III ) π A ∗ ( I ) > π B ∗ ( I ) , π A ∗ ( III ) = π B ∗ ( III ) ( if s < t ) , or p A ∗ ( I ) < p B ∗ ( I ) , p A ∗ ( III ) > p B ∗ ( III ) Δ p A ∗ ( III ) > Δ p B ∗ ( III ) θ A ∗ ( III ) > θ B ∗ ( III ) q A ∗ ( I ) > q B ∗ ( I ) , q A ∗ ( III ) = q B ∗ ( III ) π A ∗ ( I ) > π B ∗ ( I ) , π A ∗ ( III ) = π B ∗ ( III ) ( if s > t ) ; ( b ) π A ∗ ( I ) > π A ∗ ( III ) , π B ∗ ( I ) < π B ∗ ( III ) Corollary 3.3 reveals the outcome of competition and relative performance between airlines A and B before and after the implementation of the CP instrument given that the reference-dependent net mental cost, EPC i . e . , Δ P A ∗ - Δ P B ∗ , as assessed by the consumer equals the reference-dependent airfare p B ∗ - p A ∗ when choosing airlines. Let airline A be labeled the leader airline which is more cost-efficient than airline B (i.e., c A < c B ). Based on Corollary 3.3, this study provides insights below to characterize airline competitive strategies, and the changes in market share and profits under equilibrium conditions observed before and after the CP instrument. First, Proposition 2.2 shows that under equilibrium conditions, the airfare offered by the leader airline is always lower than that offered by the follower airline i . e . , p A ∗ ( I ) < p B ∗ ( I ) , resulting in the profit of the leader airline exceeding that of the follower i . e . , π A ∗ ( I ) > π B ∗ ( I ) in the scenario without CP. Next consider the case in which both competing airlines adopt airfare adjustment and GTI after implementing the CP instrument. Apparently, adopting the cost leadership strategy is advantageous to the leader airline A, similar to the case characterized in Proposition 3.1. In this case, airline A is likely to raise its airfare by a lower margin than its competitor (i.e., Δ p A ∗ ( III ) < Δ p B ∗ ( III ) ); meanwhile, airline A adopts a lower-margin GTI strategy (i.e., θ A ∗ ( III ) < θ B ∗ ( III ) ) for cost control. Such hybrid use of low-margin airfare adjustment and low-margin GTI helps airline A implement the cost leadership strategy even if the GTI-induced marginal cost (s) is less than the resulting increase in consumer utility (t) (i.e., s < t). However, the low-margin GTI measure used by the leading airline is likely to shift market share from the leading airline to its competitor, thus decreasing the profits of the leading airline compared to Scenario I (i.e., π A ∗ ( I ) > π A ∗ ( III ) ) , as observed from Corollary 3.3(a). Conversely, consider the case when GTI-induced marginal cost (s) is greater than the resulting increase in consumer utility (t), i.e., s > t. As a cost-inefficient airline, the follower (i.e., airline B) is unlikely to compete with the leading airline in GTI, particularly when s > t, because of the potential for a low rate of return on GTI. Instead, the follower tends to adopt a low-margin GTI strategy on the condition θ A ∗ ( III ) > θ B ∗ ( III ) . The resulting cost saving is likely to further facilitate airline B adopting a low-margin airfare adjustment ( Δ p A ∗ ( III ) > Δ p B ∗ ( III ) ) such that p A ∗ ( III ) > p B ∗ ( III ) to compete with airline A under the CP instrument. Consequently, the combined use of low-margin airfare adjustment and GTI by airline B shifts market share from airline A to B, leading to the outputs q A ∗ ( III ) = q B ∗ ( III ) and π A ∗ ( III ) = π B ∗ ( III ) under equilibrium conditions, as observed from Corollary 3.3(a). Nevertheless, this study observes that the leader airline (i.e., airline A) cannot achieve increased profits in Scenario III when comparing the resulting profits with those obtained in Scenario I, as shown in Corollary 3.3(b). Instead, the profits of the follower increase in Scenario III. Thus, this study concludes that given the prerequisite ( p B ∗ ( I ) - p A ∗ ( I ) > 0 ) ∧ Δ P A ∗ ( III ) - Δ P B ∗ ( III ) = p B ∗ ( I ) - p A ∗ ( I ) underlying Theorem 2.2(d), only the follower can increase their profits through airfare adjustment and GTI competition in the CP-instrument context. Corollary 3.3 is easily proved using the derived results listed in Table B-1 (online Appendix B). Observing the above qualitative analytical results yields two practical principles for cost-efficient and cost-inefficient airlines, respectively. Principle 3.1 Cost-efficient airlines can use a differentiation strategy combining high-margin airfare adjustment and high-margin GTI measures to achieve sustainable competitive advantage given condition C2. Otherwise, a cost-leadership strategy based on combining low-margin airfare adjustment and low-margin GTI measures is suggested in the CP instrument context. Principle 3.2 For cost-inefficient airlines, the differentiation strategy via combining high-margin airfare adjustment and high-margin reactive GTI measures is more likely to help them compete with cost-efficient airlines and achieve higher profits when s < t in the CP instrument context. Conversely, the cost-leadership strategy via combining low-margin airfare adjustment and low-margin GTI measures is suggested when s > t. Overall, the results of qualitative analysis presented in this study suggest that GTI positively affects market share for competing airlines, but does not invariably increase airline profits in the CP-instrument context. Instead, GTI can be used a green marketing strategy adaptive to customer attitudes toward green transportation, and as a supplement to an appropriate airfare adjustment strategy. High-margin GTI accompanied by a low-margin airfare adjustment is best for end-customers. However, such a fully customer-friendly competing strategy easily causes losses to competing airlines, and thus is not a regular suggestion from the perspective of sustainable business operations. Meanwhile, a strategic conflict exists between price competition and green transportation investment, and must be carefully addressed by competing airlines in the CP instrument context. 3.2 Quantitative analysis and results The subsequent quantitative analysis aims to analyze the influences of several primary factors, including α, c A (c B ), c cp , s and t, on the airfare adjustment and GTI strategies of competing airlines, and also on resulting profits. These factors are observed from Table B-1 (online Appendix B) as they are determinants of the equilibrium solutions derived for airfare adjustment and GTI. 3.2.1 Parameter setting To facilitate the quantitative analysis, the competition between two leading Taiwanese airline companies is illustrated. For reasons of confidentiality, the respondent airlines were labeled airlines A and B, consistent with previous definitions. Presently, six domestic airline companies are involved in the Taiwanese aviation industry. According to the Civil Aeronautics Administration of Taiwan (2011), the relative market shares of airlines A and B are about 52% and 40%, respectively, and together they account for over 90% of passenger demand in the Taiwanese air travel market, thus forming a duopoly competitive environment, as addressed in this study. The initial step in the quantitative analysis was to preset the values of parameters embedded in the proposed models, which are classified into two categories: (1) cost-related parameters (c A , c B , c cp , and s), and (2) customer-related parameters (α, t, w, λ p and λ x ). As for the cost-related parameters, this study illustrated the case of round-trips from Taipei to Paris. This study conducted preliminary analysis, as summarized below, to enhance the validity of the preset parameter values. First, this study conducted an extensive literature review (Morrell, 2007;Anger and Kohler, 2010; Scheelhaase et al., 2010;The Washington Times, 2012) to identify the unit carbon allowance price under EU-ETS, followed by approximating the marginal CP-induced cost (c cp ) per passenger for a round-trip economy-class airfare. Next, semi-structured interviews with managers and key staffs of global operations and marketing sectors of airlines A and B were conducted from March to July, 2012 to approximate the unit operational costs (c A and c B ) of the competing airlines. In total, six survey respondents joined in the interview survey (three from each airline). Nevertheless, the practices of global operations and marketing may be handled by two different sectors in an airline company. In addition to survey respondents as key informants we invited their colleagues working for these two sectors to assist them when answering the survey questions. Due to the concern of business confidentiality, we did not ask survey respondents to directly rate the unit operational costs. Instead, we approximated these two cost parameters via indirect information provided by survey respondents. For example, we asked the survey respondents for their opinions about the periods of peak, normal, and non-peak seasons for the study case (i.e., the round-trips from Taipei to Paris in a year), followed by the feasible range of the unit operational costs associated with the identified peak, normal, and non-peak periods, respectively. Furthermore, the survey respondents were questioned regarding their willingness to pay (s) for GTI measured as percentage of a unit operational cost. These cost-related parameters were then normalized by taking their raw values (obtained from survey data) divided by the annual-average economic-class airfare for a round-trip flight from Taipei to Paris, thus yielding c A =0.70, c B =0.86, c cp =0.05, and s =0.02. To estimate the customer-related parameters, this study used questionnaire survey data collected from samples of customers with experience using air transportation services provided by these two target airlines. Regarding α (i.e., percentage of customers taking airline A – used as a reference point), this study set α =0.68, based on the results of a customer survey indicating that 68% of survey respondents preferred airline A to B based on its superior safety, brand image, and service quality. Building on this analytical result, this study further assumed that airline A adopts GTI before airline B, thus giving θ A ∗ = 0.8 . The GTI-induced marginal effect (t) on consumer utility is set to 5.0 (i.e., t =5.0) for simplicity. Furthermore, let the p-specific and x-specific loss aversion coefficients (i.e., λ p and λ x ) be λ p = λ x =1.5 to comply with their lower-bound constraints λ p >1 and λ x >1, as suggested in reference dependence theory (Kahneman and Tversky, 1979; Thaler, 1985; Koszegi and Rabin, 2006); the weight (w) associated with the additional reference-dependent utility was set to w =0.5 for simplicity. Given the equilibrium solutions revealed in Theorem 2.2(d), this study conducted sensitivity analysis using the aforementioned parameter setting. The analytical results are summarized below, based on the perspectives of operations management (supply side), marketing (demand side), and EPR (non-profit side), respectively. 3.2.2 Operations management perspective From an operations management perspective, this study conjectures that a system analyst/decision maker (e.g., sector manager of an airline company) may be interested in the effect of airline cost control on competitiveness and profits. Accordingly, this study labeled airline A a target airline, and airline B a competing airline in the following numerical studies. Based on the predetermined values of parameters, this study merely adjusted the value of c A to demonstrate its effect on the margins of airfare adjustment and GTI, and the resulting airfares and profits for cases occurring before and after the implementation of the CP instrument. Furthermore, this study presented the responses of airline B in relation to airfare pricing, GTI, and resulting profits, to provide a contrast and reveal the trade-off airlines must make between competition and performance output. Fig. 6 shows the corresponding numerical results. Fig. 6 reveals several managerial implications based on the observations of this study. First, cost control appears to influence business profitability in the case without CP instrument and GTI (Scenario I), but is not a key influence in the case with CP instrument and GTI (Scenario III). This implication is drawn from the result of sensitivity analysis regarding the influence of c a on profits. Second, the difference c b − c a offers a significant criterion that a competing airline (airline B) can use to determine the margin of GTI. The analytical result with respect to the effect of c a on GTI reveals that the margin of GTI adopted by airline B increases with the difference c b − c a , resulting in these two competing airlines having equal profits π A ∗ ( III ) = π B ∗ ( III ) . This phenomenon indicates that a cost-inefficient airline (airline B) permits the utilization of the differentiation strategy (e.g., high-margin investment in green resources and services) as a competing strategy in response to the low-pricing strategy adopted by a cost-efficient airline (airline A) under the CP instrument. Third, the airfare adjustment adopted by a cost-efficient airline is not necessarily positive when competing with another airline using a high-margin GTI measure for differentiation. Instead, a cost-efficient airline can use a negative airfare adjustment (e.g., reducing the airfare under the CP-instrument) to sustain its competitive advantage. 3.2.3 Marketing perspective From a marketing perspective, it is interesting to monitor the influences of α and t on the equilibrium solutions for airline decisions regarding airfare pricing, GTI, and resulting profits. As mentioned previously, α and t characterize the fraction of consumers that use the services of airline A as a reference in airline selection, and the marginal effect of GTI on consumer utility, respectively. Similarly, this study conducted sensitivity analyses of α and t, and Figs. 7 and 8 , respectively, present the analytical results. Based on Figs. 7 and 8, the corresponding marketing implications are as follows. First, α significantly influences the decisions of competing airlines regarding airfare pricing in Scenario I; however, α does not affect airfare adjustment and GTI in Scenario III. As observed from Fig. 7, the smaller the fraction of consumers using service a as a reference point the higher the profits of airline A. This observation reveals the distinctive feature of reference-dependent consumer choice behavior, which infers that the possibility of consumers choosing airline A increases significantly if airline B is used as a reference in assessing airline A. Marketers of airline A can apply this inference to design effective marketing programs, e.g., comparative advertising, which is a popular promotion tactic that involves contrasting information on the advertised company with that of a competitor company to demonstrate the superiority of the former (Wilkie and Farris, 1975;Yagci et al., 2009). In contrast with α, parameter t appears to negatively influence the airfare adjustment and GTI of competing airlines (i.e., airline B’s), as shown in Fig. 8, supporting the results obtained for Corollary 2.5. Nevertheless, Fig. 8 only shows the significant influence of t-effect on the margin of GTI of airline B. This observation infers that as a cost-inefficient airline, airline B has inferior cost control to airline A, and consequently cannot compete on price with airline A. Instead, airline B permits differentiation of its brand image and consumer value from competitors via high-margin airfare adjustment and adaptive GTI measures as a sustainable competitive strategy, which requires a high margin of GTI when t is low, and a low margin of GTI when t is high, as shown in Fig. 8. 3.2.4 Reference-dependent behavioral perspective The following investigates the effects of w, λ p and λ x on airline market share and profits under equilibrium conditions, where w, λ p and λ x are the three primary coefficients embedded in the proposed model to characterize reference-dependent consumer attitude. Particularly, this study compares the analytical results with those obtained when w is set to zero, which leads the proposed reference-dependent consumer attitude function (V b∣a ) to an intrinsic utility (v b ) without considering the weighted reference-dependent utility (wu b∣a ). The objective is to demonstrate the difference between the results outputted from the proposed reference-dependent Hotelling model and the classical Hotelling model. Figs. 9–11 present the analytical results. Figs. 9–11 reveal several interesting findings. First, w and λ p similarly affect airline competition and performance, where the patterns of changes in airfare/airfare adjustment, GTI, market share and resulting profits are almost identical when comparing Figs. 9 and 10. The only difference is that the magnitude of changes caused by λ p appears to exceed that of changes caused by w. In contrast, the patterns of effects caused by λ x differ from those caused by w and λ p , particularly in terms of profits, which increase with λ x (Fig. 11). Consequently, a high λ x means that in airline selection consumers are more sensitive to resulting psychological benefits than to perceived airfares. Thus, Fig. 11 shows that the increase in λ x contributes to increases in airfares and profits among airlines. Moreover, by comparing the output yielded given w =0 and w >0 (Fig. 9) this study provides several insights characterizing the difference in model projections between the proposed reference-dependent consumer behavioral model and classical behavioral models without the effect of reference dependence. First, this study observes that the increase in weight w is likely to decrease airfares and profits for all airlines (Fig. 9). This observation is consistent with expectations regarding reference-dependent consumer behavior. From a reference-dependent perspective, consumers tend to choose an airline service by comparing the relative performance of competing airlines, including prices and green transportation efforts, as well as resulting psychological benefits, rather than comparing simply based on personal preference. Therein, high w indicates high influence orientation based on the additive reference-dependent utility. Accordingly, consumers exhibiting significant features of reference-dependent choice behavior may favor intense competition among airlines, leading to lower forecast airfares when w >0 than without the reference-dependent effect (i.e., when w =0). Furthermore, this study observes that the market share of airline A (the cost-efficient airline) increases, and that of airline B (the cost-inefficient airline) decreases with increasing w in Scenario I (without CP instrument and GTI). This study thus infers that reference-dependent choice behavior benefits the cost-efficient airline by helping it expand its market share. 4 Conclusions and recommendations This study proposes a methodology based on behavioral economics theory to analyze airline competition in airfare pricing and green transportation investment, and resulting performance under the ETS-CP instrument. The proposed approach applies reference dependence theory in characterizing consumer attitudes towards airfare prices and disutility when choosing airline services, followed by approximating the aggregate demands, i.e., the relative market share of airlines using the Hotelling model. Next, this study investigates the equilibrium solutions contingent on specific conditions which consider the net psychological benefits/costs of consumers, and airline leadership in cost efficiency for the decisions of competing airlines regarding airfare adjustment and GTI margins in different CP-instrument scenarios. The analytical results presented in this study indicate that in the GTI-free case, competing airlines tend to raise airfares by a margin equal to the CP-induced unit cost (c cp ) under equilibrium conditions in response to the CP instrument. Thus, the profits gained by airlines remain unchanged. Furthermore, this study also identifies specific conditions that may favor the implementation of a differentiation strategy by either a cost-efficient or cost-inefficient airline to increase its profits relative to competitors. For example, a cost-efficient airline can achieve competitive advantage in both market share and profitability by increasing the margins of airfare adjustment and GTI to exceed those of competitors in the CP-instrument context if the C2 condition of Proposition 3.1 holds. Conversely, a cost-inefficient airline can compete with a cost-efficient airline in both market share and profitability by allocating more resources than competitors to greening its transportation services if the necessary condition of Theorem 2.2(d) holds. Additionally, using GTI as a green marketing strategy adaptive to customer attitudes toward green transportation positively affects market share of competing airlines, and is not guaranteed to increase airline profits in the CP-instrument context. Although the proposed methodology and generalizations advance knowledge of reference-dependent consumer choice behavior and how it interacts with airline competition in scenarios involving the CP instrument, this study suggests several future research directions. First, this study suggests incorporating heterogeneity in consumer characteristics via elaborate experimental design and behavioral parameter estimation into the proposed reference-dependent Hotelling model. Second, this work focuses on symmetric duopoly competition, which assumes airlines are similar in all economic aspects and compete for the same consumer categories (Schemalensee, 1976). In reality, model extension to incorporate competition among airlines with different market power structure and target markets deserves more research. Diverse competing strategies adopted by competitors and their influences on reference-dependent consumer choice behavior also deserve investigation. Moreover, it is noteworthy that the cost of GTI may exist in any other forms in practical cases. Presently, this work introduces the variable of the degree of GTI (θ) and the associated marginal cost (s) which is assumed to be a constant to facilitate conducting the analyses, thus requiring additional efforts to make the forms of GTI costs fit for practical cases in future research. Furthermore, future studies can consider different CP instrument options. For example, Preston et al. (2012) noted the need to develop more appropriate methods for allocating emissions to airlines within the EU-ETS. Egenhofer (2007) further argued that the method of allocating emission allowances to emitters (e.g., airlines) adopted by EU-ETS represents a compromise, and is less efficient than auctioning. Accordingly, only a small proportion of emission allowances are auctioned without considering the heterogeneity of airline green performance, e.g., the effort and outcome expended on improving carbon emissions and green transportation. More recently, ICAO member states have achieved the agreement to grant exemptions for applying such CP measures on routes departing to and from developing countries whose share of international civil aviation activities is below 1% of total revenue ton kilometers of international civil aviation activities, before a global scheme is rolled out. A short-term effect of such incentives is cost reduction to those airlines departing from and to developing countries, compared with other airlines. Therein, extending the proposed methodology by revising the CP-induced cost with an additional term of cost discounts can be an alternative means of addressing the above issue. However, additional research effort in either empirical studies or quantitative analyses is apparently needed to investigate the resulting long-term effect on global aviation industries. Additionally, the issue of emissions trading within the aviation sector and between the aviation sector and other sectors under the EU ETS is notable. The EU ETS permits airlines to trade their carbon emission allowances within the aviation sector or purchase allowances from other sectors, but simultaneously prevents airlines from selling their allowances to other sectors. Therefore, the resulting impact on airline willingness to implement GTI and aviation competition requires further investigation. In sum, this study contributes to the literature on behavioral economics, green transportation, and consumer behavior, and makes incremental contributions to service industry sustainability using a novel reference-dependent behavioral methodology. We hope this study will stimulate further interdisciplinary research on the above areas. A.8 Corollary 2.4 and proof This study observes that the factors influencing equilibrium solutions can be classified into two categories: (1) cost-related parameters (c A , c B , c cp , and s), and (2) demand-related parameters (α, t, w, λ p and λ x ). Among these influences, airlines can only control c A and c B (i.e., the marginal operational costs of competing airlines); the other influences are determined externally by either third-party intervention (e.g., c cp determined by EU-CTS, and s determined by green technology suppliers) or consumer attitudes (α, t, w, λ p and λ x ). Furthermore, demonstrating how these key operating and marketing characteristics influence the equilibrium solutions Δ p ̃ A ∗ , Δ p ̃ B ∗ , θ A ∗ , and θ B ∗ by taking corresponding first-order conditions is straightforward. Corollary 2.4 illustrates the signs of the effects of these parameters on decision variables. Corollary 2.4 Given Theorem 2.2 , and s < t, the following is true. (see Table A-1 ) Conditions: ( 1 ) : + if θ B ∗ > t [ 3 - 2 ( c A - c B ) L ] 2 ( t - s ) 2 L , - otherwise ( for Theorem 2.2 ( b ) ) ( 2 ) : + if θ A ∗ > t [ 3 - 2 ( c B - c A ) K ] 2 ( t - s ) 2 K , - otherwise ( for Theorem 2.2 ( a ) ) ( 3 ) : α [ ( λ p - 1 ) ( 1 + w λ x ) 2 + ( λ x - 1 ) ( 1 + w ) 2 ] > ( λ x - 1 ) ( 1 + w ) 2 or α [ ( λ x - 1 ) ( 1 + w ) 2 + ( λ p - 1 ) ( 1 + w λ x ) 2 ] > ( λ p - 1 ) ( 1 + w λ x ) 2 Overall, the effects of parameters on decision variables revealed in Corollary 2.4 provide several interesting findings. First, for a given airline, the sign of the effect of a unit operational cost on airfare adjustment is consistent with that of its effect on GTI. For example, Δ p ̃ A ∗ and θ A ∗ increase with increasing c A , indicating that an airline is likely to adopt high-margin airfare adjustment and GTI measures when the unit operational cost increases in the CP-instrument context. Owing to competition, the signs of the effects of unit operational costs differ between competing airlines. Furthermore, unit CP-induced cost (c cp ) positively affects airfare adjustment, and the effect is congruent for all competing airlines. This inference resembles the case in which fuel prices increase worldwide, increasing airfares of global airlines. Nevertheless, it is surprising that c cp does not affect GTI. Consequently, this study infers that the EU-ETS does not differentiate airlines based on their green efforts and performance (e.g., improvement in carbon emission) when charging CPs to airplanes arriving at and departing from EU airports, and thus, c cp does not influence the margin of GTI. In contrast, the effects of s and t are irregular, and contingent on other specific situations. As such, the CP-induced marginal cost (s) positively affects airfare adjustments ( Δ p ̃ A ∗ and Δ p ̃ B ∗ ). However, the increase in s is likely to negatively affect GTI, because it reduces the willingness of an airline to invest in green transportation. This inference holds particularly when an airline is either cost-inefficient or a follower in GTI, as indicated in Corollary 2.4 and the associated proof. Conversely, the increase in t (i.e., the marginal effect of GTI on consumer utility) is likely to stimulate airline willingness to be involved in GTI, a phenomena particularly true for GTI followers, thus positively affecting the margin of GTI. As for the effects of w, α, λ p , and λ x , the analytical results of Corollary 2.4 provide managerial insights to help bridge the gap between the analyses of disaggregate consumer behavior and aggregate marketing competition. From a reference-dependence perspective (Kahneman and Tversky, 1979;Thaler, 1985; Koszegi and Rabin, 2006), the weight (w) characterizes the relative influence of the reference-dependent utility of a consumer (u b∣a ) in assessing air transportation services. Given that airline A is both the most cost efficient airline and the reference point, the increase in w represents the increase in the influence of u b∣a on consumer assessment of the service value of airline B compared with that of airline A. To sustain competitive advantage in airfare pricing, airline A is more likely to adopt a smaller airfare adjustment together with a lower margin of GTI to increase its profitability together with increasing w. Therefore, negative effects on Δ p ̃ A ∗ and θ A ∗ are observed in Corollary 2.4. Conversely, airline B, which is less cost efficient than airline A, is more likely to adopt a higher-margin GTI measure to increase consumer mental benefit, and simultaneously is likely to adopt a higher-margin airfare adjustment to compensate for increased GTI expenses, contributing to the phenomenon of w positively affecting Δ p ̃ B ∗ and θ B ∗ . A similar situation occurs with the effects of α (i.e., the fraction of consumers taking airline A as a reference point in the demand market), where the signs of α-induced effects are consistent with those of w-induced effects (Corollary 2.4). In contrast, λ p , and λ x represent the loss aversion coefficients associated with the price (p) and psychological benefit (x) domains of consumer attitude, and have opposite effects on decision variables, as expected. For example, the increase in λ p is likely to increase consumer aversion to choosing an airline with higher airfares, helping a cost-efficient airline adopt a low-margin airfare adjustment measure. This is also why the sign of the λ p -induced effect on Δ p ̃ A ∗ is “–” when airline A is more cost-efficient than airline B. The proof of Corollary 2.4 is given as follows. Given Δ p ̃ A ∗ , Δ p ̃ B ∗ , θ A ∗ , and θ B ∗ (Eqs. (24)–(27) of Theorem 2.2), we take their first-order conditions with respect to c A , c B , c cp , s, t, w, α, λ p , λ x , respectively. coredata.dc:description: Abstract This study presents a reference-dependent Hotelling model for analyzing airline competition in pricing and green transportation investment, as well as the resulting financial performance under the European Union emission trading scheme. One feature of the proposed methodology is that it embeds psychological benefits/costs of consumers to characterize consumer attitudes to the increases in airline fare adjustments and improvements in green transportation. This study then investigates the equilibrium solutions for airfare adjustment and green transportation investment margins in different scenarios. The analytical results reveal specific operational conditions under which a cost-efficient airline can gain supreme competitive advantage by increasing both airfare and green transportation investment margins beyond the increases made by competitors under the emission trading scheme, whereas certain specific conditions may favor a cost leadership strategy. Conversely, a cost-inefficient airline can compete with a cost-efficient airline in both market share and profitability using the green transportation investment-differentiation strategy, particularly when consumers perceive the airfare difference as equaling the increased psychological benefit induced by the airline’s green effort.
coredata.dc:title: Airline ambidextrous competition under an emissions trading scheme – A reference-dependent behavioral perspective
